Cambridge City
MA

City Manager's Agenda Item
CMA 2024 #252

A communication transmitted from Yi-An Huang, City Manager, relative to Awaiting Report Item number 24-37, regarding a request for the City Manager to work with relevant City departments to consider a number of city application processes and find ways to reduce paper and printing waste.

Information

Department:City Manager's OfficeSponsors:
Category:Awaiting Report Response

Links

OriginAR-24-37 : That the City Manager is requested to work with relevant City departments to consider a number of city application processes and find ways to reduce paper and printing waste.
Originating Order

Attachments

Version History
  1. Printout

Body

 

 

 

To the Honorable, the City Council:

 

In response to Awaiting Report item # 24-37, regarding a request for the City Manager to work with relevant City departments to consider a number of city application processes and find ways to reduce paper and printing waste. Please see below communication from Patrick McCormick, Chief Information Officer and Iram Farooq, Assistant City Manager for Community Development.

 

Over the past several years, the City of Cambridge has made significant progress shifting from paper-based to online permits, licensing, applications, and other business processes. Benefits of moving these processes online include business efficiency, constituent convenience, error reduction, and environmental sustainability. While some processes still necessitate paper-based options, most have been or are being moved online through close collaboration between department business owners and the IT department (ITD).

 

Since adopting a modern and adaptable online services platform from OpenGov (previously Viewpoint) in 2017, the City has been in a better position to design and develop online permits, licenses, and applications, collectively known as “records”, that align closely to departmental business requirements and end user preferences. The OpenGov platform has also evolved, in part through ongoing leadership and input from the City of Cambridge to better suit municipal government and City requirements.

 

Progress implementing online records has been measured and reported annually through the budget process with the number of new records created each year listed in the ITD budget summary. While the number of records digitized each year conveys the general volume of progress, it should be noted that certain records are more complex than others and thus can take longer to develop, test, and implement.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

The table below includes the number of records implemented, as well as a description of highlights and areas of focus for each FY.

 

 

YEAR

NUMBER

HIGHLIGHTS

Multiple

87

Online records migrated from legacy IT systems to OpenGov

2017

4

OpenGov (previously Viewpoint) purchased and implemented. Focus on License Commission records required to be renewed by end of year.

2018

49

Focus on remaining priority License Commission records ITD team member embedded within ISD to map out business processes and move records online. Animal Control records implemented in OpenGov.

2019

29

DPW records migrated from EnerGov system to OpenGov platform.

2020

23

Specialty permits prioritized due to Covid-19 pandemic. Traffic and Parking records implemented. Assessing begins migration at end of FY.

2021

35

Fire Department moved most records to OpenGov. DHSP piloted lotteries in OpenGov and proved successful. ISD added sanitary records. License Commission migrated lower priority records.

2022

16

Assessing implemented online tax exemption forms. Water Department implemented online records within OpenGov.

2023

9

CDD implemented 3 distinct online affordable housing lotteries.

2024

9

Multi-departmental collaboration to implement municipal ticketing records within OpenGov

TOTAL

261

Overall number records now available on OpenGov platform

 

 

For FY25 there are another (10) records currently under development on the OpenGov platform, including Assessing, Arts, and Electrical transactions. Additional records are currently under review and anticipated to be made available online in FY25 and FY26. While digital records and processes are now standard for most City services, there are certain areas, transactions, and users that demand some paper-based materials and documentation:

 

·         Legal Compliance and Record Keeping: Certain permits and licenses require physical copies to meet state and federal regulations, particularly in cases involving long-term records retention or sensitive legal documentation requiring timestamps.

·         Large-Scale Building Plans: For projects involving extensive architectural and engineering plans, physical submissions are occasionally required due to the size and complexity of the documents. This ensures comprehensive review and accuracy in meeting safety, zoning, and construction standards.

·         Planning Board Applications: These applications tend to include more materials than typical permit applications. In general, these materials are submitted and circulated electronically by Community Development Department (CDD) staff. However, some materials need to be submitted in print version for official filing. There are also certain materials, like plans, that some Planning Board members and staff will request in printed format to facilitate review. CDD staff actively work with applicants, Planning Board members, and staff to determine the number of print copies necessary to meet these needs and avoid unnecessary waste.

 

 

Given the benefits of business efficiency, constituent convenience, error reduction, and environmental sustainability, and the proven success and adaptability of the current online records platform, the City is committed to moving services online wherever possible. ITD will continue to collaborate with departments to adapt, streamline and optimize online services to meet the needs of residents and businesses while ensuring an increasingly sustainable delivery of municipal services.

 

 

Very truly yours,

 

Yi-An Huang

City Manager
